article.para: If you wish to run Samba on your firewall and access shares between the firewall and local hosts, you need the following rules:
article.programlisting: #ACTION SOURCE DEST PROTO DEST PORT(S) SOURCE # PORT(S) SMB/ACCEPT fw loc SMB/ACCEPT loc fw
article.para: To pass traffic SMB/Samba traffic between zones Z1 and Z2:
article.programlisting: #ACTION SOURCE DEST PROTO DEST PORT(S) SOURCE # PORT(S) SMB/ACCEPT Z1 Z2 SMB/ACCEPT Z2 Z1
article.para: To make network browsing (Network Neighborhood) work properly between Z1 and Z2 requires a Windows Domain Controller and/or a WINS server. I have run Samba on my firewall to handle browsing between two zones connected to my firewall.
When debugging Samba/SMB problems, I recommend that you do the following:

listitem.para: Copy action.Drop and action.Reject from /usr/share/shorewall to /etc/shorewall.
Edit the copies and remove the SMB/DROP and SMB/REJECT lines.

article.para: The above steps will cause SMB traffic that is dropped or rejected by policy to be logged rather than handled silently.
You can just remove the copies and shorewall restart when you are finished debugging.
